title: Explain how to use `ScheduleLabel`s in `bevy_ecs`

labels.name: C-Docs
labels.description: An addition or correction to our documentation

labels.name: S-Ready-For-Implementation
labels.description: This issue is ready for an implementation PR. Go for it!

body:
I am trying to use `bevy_ecs` standalone (i.e. no `App` or other Bevy components yet) and was confused about how to manage the _schedules_ I create. I got some advice which cleared things up, and I now have the following suggestions for documentation improvements that could have helped me get the right idea from the start:

* In <https://docs.rs/bevy_ecs/0.16.0/bevy_ecs/schedule/trait.ScheduleLabel.html>, document that this trait has an accompanying derive macro, and give an example of using it. Right now, it's not clear how a user of `bevy_ecs` creates and uses a schedule label; the only implementor visible when looking at `bevy_ecs` (not `bevy`) is `Interned<dyn ScheduleLabel>`. (I had vaguely acquired the entirely wrong impression that schedule labels are auto-assigned IDs like `Entity`. I could have been reminded this was wrong by rereading normal `bevy` usage docs, but ideally `bevy_ecs` docs by themselves would suffice.)

* In <https://docs.rs/bevy_ecs/0.16.0/bevy_ecs/schedule/struct.Schedule.html> (the type documentation, not any specific function), add some sentences about how schedule labels relate to schedules.

* In <https://docs.rs/bevy_ecs/0.16.0/bevy_ecs/world/struct.World.html#method.run_schedule>, expand on the sentence “For simple testing use cases, call [Schedule::run(&mut world)](https://docs.rs/bevy_ecs/0.16.0/bevy_ecs/schedule/struct.Schedule.html#method.run) instead.” with a rationale, perhaps, “This avoids the need to create a unique `ScheduleLabel`.”

* In <https://docs.rs/bevy_ecs/0.16.0/bevy_ecs/world/struct.World.html#method.add_schedule>, mention that if one's goal is to add systems that are organized into schedules, one might want to use <https://docs.rs/bevy_ecs/latest/bevy_ecs/schedule/struct.Schedules.html#method.add_systems>, as opposed to the naïve direct approach of calling `Schedule::new()` and working with that.
